items.title: Interstellar comet releases water far from sun

featured_image.name: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule ...

items.description:
Astronomers have confirmed that the rare interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS is a natural comet, not an alien spacecraft, following the most comprehensive radio signal search ever conducted on an object from beyond the solar system. The confirmation comes as new observations reveal the comet is releasing water at extraordinary rates and may be among the oldest objects ever observed, potentially dating back 7 to 14 billion years[1][2][3].

Results published this week from the Breakthrough Listen initiative show that multiple radio telescopes, including the Green Bank Telescope, detected no artificial signals during observations conducted as the comet made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, 2025[1][4]. The Green Bank facility, the world's largest fully-steerable radio telescope, ruled out transmitters down to 0.1 watts—ten times weaker than a typical cell phone—during observations on December 18[1][5][6].

items.title: Study finds aviation emissions could be cut by up to 75%

featured_image.name: Aviation likely to be the UK's leading emitter by 2040 ...

items.description:
Global aviation emissions could be reduced by 50 to 75 percent through three efficiency strategies already within reach: deploying the most fuel-efficient aircraft, eliminating premium cabin seating, and filling more seats on each flight, according to a study published Tuesday in Nature Communications Earth & Environment[1][2][3].

The research, co-led by the University of Oxford and Linnaeus University, analyzed more than 27 million commercial flights in 2023, revealing that airlines could achieve an 11 percent reduction in emissions immediately by better allocating their existing efficient aircraft on routes they already operate[1][2][3].

"Our results clearly show that efficiency-focused policy could swiftly reduce aviation emissions by more than half, without reducing flight numbers or waiting for future fuels," said co-author Dr. Milan Klöwer of Oxford's Department of Physics[2][3]. "These are tools that we can use right now."

items.title: US seizes second Venezuelan oil tanker in Caribbean

featured_image.name: U.S. launches operation to seize Russian-flagged oil tanker linked to ...

items.description:
U.S. forces seized a second sanctioned oil tanker linked to Venezuela on Wednesday, conducting back-to-back operations in the Caribbean and North Atlantic as President Donald Trump escalates enforcement of his blockade on Venezuelan oil exports.

The M/T Sophia, described by U.S. Southern Command as a "stateless, sanctioned dark fleet motor tanker," was apprehended in a predawn operation in international waters of the Caribbean Sea[1][2]. The Panama-flagged supertanker had departed Venezuelan waters in early January, operating with its transponder turned off in "dark mode" as part of a fleet carrying Venezuelan oil to China[3][4][5].

items.title: Morocco fossils illuminate split between humans, Neanderthals

featured_image.name: Moroccan Cave Fossils Yield a Possible Missing Link in Human Evolution

items.description:
Scientists unveiled Wednesday the discovery of 773,000-year-old hominin fossils in Morocco that may represent populations living near the evolutionary crossroads where modern humans, Neanderthals, and Denisovans diverged—filling a critical gap in the African fossil record and reinforcing Africa as the birthplace of our species[1][2][3][4].

The fossils, published in Nature, were unearthed from Grotte à Hominidés, a cave at the Thomas Quarry I site near Casablanca[1][2][3]. An international research team led by Jean-Jacques Hublin of the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology in Germany analyzed three partial jawbones—including one from a child—along with several vertebrae and teeth[1][2][5][6][3]. The remains display a mosaic of primitive features resembling Homo erectus and more modern traits seen in later humans[1][5][3].

items.title: China orders tech firms to halt Nvidia H200 chip purchases

featured_image.name: Nvidia Announces H200 GPU: 141GB of HBM3e and 4.8 TB/s ...

items.description:
Just one day after Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang touted "very high" Chinese demand for the company's H200 AI chips, Beijing has instructed tech companies to temporarily halt orders for the processors, according to multiple reports[1][2].

The directive, reported by Reuters and The Information on January 7, marks an abrupt reversal following the Trump administration's December decision to allow sales of the advanced chips to China[1][2]. The move underscores Beijing's push for semiconductor self-sufficiency even as US export licenses remain pending approval.

items.title: Chinese software flags possible B-21 bomber flaws

featured_image.name: China's stealth design software PADJ-X finds potential flaws in B-21 bomber configuration

items.description:
Chinese researchers have developed advanced simulation software that suggests potential aerodynamic and stability shortcomings in publicly available designs of the United States' B-21 Raider stealth bomber, according to a study published last month in a peer-reviewed aerospace journal.

The software system, called PADJ-X, was detailed in December 2025 by researchers led by Huang Jiangtao from the China Aerodynamics Research and Development Centre in a paper published in Acta Aeronautica et Astronautica Sinica[1][2][3][4]. Using the platform to analyze a B-21-type configuration with 288 parameters, the team found that aerodynamic optimization could increase the aircraft's lift-to-drag ratio by approximately 15 percent and improve the pitching moment from -0.2 to nearly zero, suggesting the current design may not achieve optimal stability for level flight[1][2][4].

The research comes as the B-21 Raider, built by Northrop Grumman, undergoes intensive flight testing at Edwards Air Force Base in California[4][5][6]. A second test aircraft joined the program in September 2025, marking what Air Force Secretary Troy Meink called "substantial momentum" for the sixth-generation stealth bomber[5][6][7].

items.title: Venezuela stocks surge on Maduro ouster, US oil deal

featured_image.name: Venezuela bonds are the hottest trade on Wall Street this week, but ...

items.description: Venezuela's stock market soared in the days following the January 3 capture of President Nicolás Maduro by US forces, with the Caracas Stock Exchange's IBC index surging 50% on Tuesday and adding another 16% on Monday—a combined gain of roughly 73% since the military operation[1][2][3]. The rally reflects investor optimism about potential economic reforms, though skeptics warn meaningful opportunities remain distant without political transition.

items.title: US forces seize Russian-flagged oil tanker after Atlantic chase

featured_image.name: Russia Sends Naval Vessel to Escort Oil Tanker U.S. Is Pursuing

items.description:
US military and Coast Guard personnel successfully boarded the Marinera, a Russian-flagged oil tanker linked to Venezuela, in the North Atlantic on January 7 before Russian naval escorts could arrive, according to US officials[1][2][3]. The seizure caps a dramatic two-week chase across the Atlantic and marks a significant escalation in tensions between Washington and Moscow over Venezuela's shadow fleet oil trade.

The operation was conducted by US special operations forces using MH-6 Little Bird helicopters from the elite 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment, with imagery released by Russian state media showing the aircraft operating near the vessel[1][4]. US officials confirmed that boarding personnel, including Coast Guard members, secured the tanker before Russian surface vessels and a submarine dispatched to escort it could reach the scene[1][5].

items.title: Scientists extract DNA from da Vinci artwork

featured_image.name: Searching for the 'genetic footprint' of Leonardo da Vinci - Earth.com

items.description:
In a remarkable development five centuries after his death, researchers have recovered trace DNA from Renaissance artifacts that may belong to Leonardo da Vinci, potentially offering unprecedented insights into the legendary polymath's genetic heritage.

Scientists from the Leonardo da Vinci DNA Project reported in a study published Monday that they successfully extracted minuscule DNA samples from a red chalk drawing titled "Holy Child," possibly created by da Vinci, and from letters written by his ancestor Frosino di Ser Giovanni da Vinci[1][2]. The findings, first reported by Science Magazine, represent a milestone in the decade-long effort to reconstruct Leonardo's genetic profile[4].

items.title: CES 2026 highlights AI integration in toys, health tech

featured_image.name: Razer's AI gaming assistant, Project Ava, has a physical form now

items.description: The annual Consumer Electronics Show opened its doors in Las Vegas this week with artificial intelligence taking center stage across nearly every product category, from interactive toys to health monitoring devices. Day 2 of the exhibition, which runs through January 9, featured keynote presentations from major technology companies and hundreds of product demonstrations emphasizing how AI is moving from abstract concept to practical application[1][2][3].

items.title: US forces seize Russian-flagged oil tanker with Venezuela links
items.description: The tanker has been evading an American blockade of sanctioned vessels linked to Venezuela's oil industry since December.

items.title: Gunshot at rural WA property prompts police search for 58yo man, woman injured
items.description: Police are urging anyone who sees Kenneth John Giles or a white ute to call Triple Zero, as significant resources are deployed.

items.title: Hottest day in years recorded as bushfire warnings remain
items.description: South-east Australia has sweltered through its hottest day in years as firefighters in Victoria continue to battle multiple out-of-control blazes.

items.title: UK citizen described as 'good friend' by White Australia movement to be deported
items.description: A foreign national has his visa cancelled and is facing deportation from Australia, amid claims of links to the "White Australia" movement.

items.title: England's brightest hope and biggest blunder sets up Sydney finale
items.description: Jacob Bethell's brilliant maiden Test century sets up an intriguing finish in Sydney, but leaves everyone bemused as to where this precocious young player has been all summer.

items.title: Aboriginal artist Bobbi Lockyer in tears as Australia Post loses $4k painting
items.description: Indigenous artist Bobbi Lockyer has been left frustrated after she sent a $4,000 custom artwork of the Pilbara to a buyer in Queensland, only for an empty cardboard sleeve to be delivered.

items.title: 'It feels wrong': Final Bondi terror attack funeral held in Sydney
items.description: A retired detective has been remembered as an "incredibly moral and honest man" at a funeral service three weeks after he was killed in the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: The US may have Nicolás Maduro but 'the prince' remains in Caracas
items.description: Nicolás Maduro Guerra rose through the ranks of his father's government and remains in Caracas. It's uncertain for how long.

items.title: 'Very pleasant surprise': Inflation cools but remains above RBA target
items.description: Inflation cooled in November, with the consumer price index rising 3.4 per cent over the year, down from 3.8 per cent a month earlier. Some economists continue to forecast a February rate hike, however.

items.title: A vast expanse, a missing woman, and doubt she's even out there at all
items.description: Angie Fuller has been missing for three years. Police are offering an equal record reward for information into what they believe is a suspected outback murder.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
